text: in the last hour Jeremy Corbyn has
written to the Prime Minister to tell
her that talks to find a compromise
agreement for leaving the European Union
have gone as far as they can he blames
the splits within the government saying
in the letter the increasing weakness
and instability of your government means
there cannot be confidence in securing
whatever might be agreed between us as I
said when we met on Tuesday evening
there's been growing concern both in the
shadow cabinet and parliamentary Labour
Party about the government's ability to
deliver on any compromise agreement well
our political correspondent Jonathan
Blake is at Westminster we knew this was
coming but it's an important day
Jonathan certainly is there were life in
that torturous at times process of talks
between the government and labour that's
been going on for six weeks or so now in
an attempt to try to find a compromise
that both sides could be happy with and
both sides could sell to their parties
in order to win a vote in the House of
Commons but although as you say there
and as mr. Corbin acknowledges in this
letter to the Prime Minister there were
significant areas of agreement between
the Tories and labour on the detail of
the policy it was perhaps the political
reality that stopped the two sides being
able to do a deal that they would be
able to bring their parties on board
with not least because on the labor side
there are many Labour MPs who would like
to see a confirmation vote another
referendum as part of any deal with the
government and deep uneasiness as well
among Labour MPs about doing a deal with
the Tories when they may well end up
with a new leader in just a few months
time who could rip the whole thing up
and start again and then on the
conservative side you had deep
uneasiness about even talking to labour
and potentially doing a deal and on the
issue of a customs union with the
European Union a key labour demand while
we saw just last week how many many
Conservative MPs would regard that as a
step too far so it is Jeremy Corbyn
who's taken the step and pulled the plug
on these talks and said that they've
gone as far as they can he ends the
letter by saying that he will look
constructively at any proposals the
government brings forward to try to
break the brexit deadlock and to
try to get something through the House
of Commons but then goes on to say that
without significant changes labour will
continue to oppose the Prime Minister's
deal so it's effectively Jeremy Corbyn
saying your move now to resume but we're
done with this process well and it's not
clear that it really is her move is it
because you know that is my next
question to you Jonathan we've got a
Tory leadership campaign in the offing
yes it's been underway unofficially for
weeks now with Theresa Mays position
increasingly precarious in Downing
Street but with her confirmation
yesterday that after Parliament will get
another vote on her brexit deal in the
first full week of June she will then
set a timetable for her departure which
if she loses that vote I think we can
expect to kick in pretty much
immediately but runners and riders now
throwing the hat into the ring thick and
fast and jostling for position to win
not only the admiration and support and
votes of conservative MPs in the first
instance but then the wider grassroots
Tory membership across the UK who will
select the final winner and we've got
three of those contenders out and about
officially confirming that they are in
the contest Boris Johnson the former
foreign secretary confirming yesterday
that absolutely he will have a shot at
the job which he has fancied for so long
and then you have a couple of other hats
in the ring esta McVeigh the Work and
Pensions Secretary has said that she
would like to have a shot at being Prime
Minister and a relative newcomer to the
cabinet Rory Stewart the new
international development secretary has
been casting for support as well so in
addition to those three there are
several other familiar names and faces
in the cabinet who may or may not
officially at some points be a part of
this contest but all of them it has to
be said with leadership ambitions you've
got the Environment Secretary Michael
Gove a leader of the house Andrea led
some on that list as well the health
secretary Matt Hancock Penny Morden the
new Defense Secretary Sajid Javid the
Home Secretary and the Foreign Secretary
Jeremy Hunt as well so the list goes on
and it's a very long one at this stage
but over the next few weeks and months
it will be whittled down
to by conservative MPs and then as I say
the wider Tory membership across the UK
will select their new leader and with
that the country's new prime minister
Jonathan thank you
